nodes.text: Intergenerational income mobility in the United States varies across places and can be characterized and related to local factors using administrative income records
Method: Use deidentified federal income tax records covering over 40 million children and their parents (1996–2012) to link parents and children and measure incomes

Method: Define and compare mobility measures — intergenerational earnings elasticity (IGE, log-log), rank-rank slope (relative mobility), and absolute mobility (predicted child national percentile given parent percentile, focus on r25)

Result (national): Rank-rank relationship is nearly perfectly linear nationally; a 10 percentile increase in parent rank associates with a 3.41 percentile increase in child rank (rank-rank slope = 0.341)

Result: The canonical log-log IGE is unstable and sensitive to nonlinearities and treatment of zero incomes (estimated IGEs range roughly 0.26–0.70 depending on specification), making rank-rank preferable for robustness

Result (spatial): Intergenerational mobility varies substantially across commuting zones (CZs); e.g., probability of moving from bottom to top quintile is 4.4% in Charlotte vs 12.9% in San Jose; r25 ranges from about 35.8 to about 46.2 among largest CZs

Claim: Areas with higher upward mobility are associated with five observable features: (i) less residential segregation, (ii) less income inequality (especially among bottom 99%), (iii) better K–12 school outputs, (iv) greater social capital, and (v) greater family stability

Evidence: CZ-level correlations — fraction single-parent households strongly negatively correlated with upward mobility (approximately -0.76 unweighted); racial segregation, income Gini (bottom 99%), social capital index, income-adjusted school outcomes, and short commute share also strongly correlated with mobility

Method: Assign children to CZ where they grew up (ZIP at age when first claimed) and estimate CZ-level rank-rank regressions Ric = alpha_c + beta_c Pi to obtain CZ intercepts and slopes; slope = relative mobility, intercept+25*slope = r25 absolute upward mobility
Result: The rank-rank relationship is approximately linear within CZs as well, so CZ mobility can be summarized by slope (relative) and intercept (absolute, e.g., r25)

Result (intermediates): Children's college attendance and teenage birth rates are strongly and linearly related to parent rank (10-pp increase in parent rank -> ~6.7 pp higher college attendance; ~3 pp lower teen birth for women); college quality also correlated

Claim/Evidence: Spatial patterns of intermediate outcomes (college attendance, teen birth rates, employment) mirror income mobility patterns, implying that local factors shaping intermediates are linked to long-run income mobility

Evidence/Robustness: Relationships hold after controlling for parental income and demographics; multiple sensitivity checks (alternate samples, different income definitions, handling of zeros) produce qualitatively similar spatial patterns

Conclusion: Administrative tax data reveal substantial geographic variation in intergenerational mobility; observable local characteristics correlate with mobility and intermediates, suggesting targets for further causal investigation and policy
